Its been a while since I caught up on international emission laws. I don't think the F.A.A. can guarantee that all the devices on a plane comply with FCC emission laws. As such a device that emits a lot more EMI than the devices you give as examples could be on board.

It would be unfair and absurd to allow some devices to be used on a plane and disallow others.

"There have been fewer than a hundred anecdotal reports despite hundreds of million of flights flown. No government report has stated there is conclusive proof."

The fact that there are reports of it happening means it happens, such no conclusive proof exists however no counter proof exists either.

If 12% of passengers get away with leaving their cellphones on (unintentionally, I'm sure . . . ), what prevents the terrorist from leaving a modified cellphone on? And even with a device that listens for a problem signal, nothing will stop said terrorist from turning on that hypothetical modified cellphone long enough to bring down the plane, if indeed it is possible for a modified cellphone to do that.

So, either passengers have to be prevented from carrying cellphones on board (good luck with that!), or all cellphones carried on board have to be screened (oh, goody, another thing to check - if that would even be sufficient) or the systems that could be impacted by a cellphone (or a modified cellphone) have to be protected. In which case, it would not be necessary to ban the use of cellphones. Other than to protect the sanity of other passengers, of course.

(These comments, including mine, are a bit off-topic; the article was about Kindles, not cell phones.)

Bravo for including some original research on this. See also:

* C-Span footage of numerous hearings on the matter (they all center on cellphone conversations being a nuisance to passengers - not a security concern).

* Carnegie-Mellon study, which put a simplified cell receiver of their own and waited for cellphones to connect to it in the overhead on several flights. On average 12% of the passengers left a cellphone on for the entirety of the flights they tested.

The "entire plane full of cellphones" argument holds no water. A terrorist can make a lot more noise with one modified device than an entire plane full of innocent passengers, cells left on. Either the noise can bring a plane down, and we have a very serious security concern due to poor engineering, or the planes we fly on aren't vulnerable and this rule is crap. Only one of these is true. I'd be interested in further research showing exactly which it is.

Modify a cellphone, and don't just test "Did it make the instruments a little weird," would it be enough to screw up a pilot and if so under what conditions? It's dangerous information to some degree, but if for example the answer was "Only if there was zero visibility during the final stages of landing," then the rule should be strictly enforced by a device that listens for problem signal - stewardesses walking around won't catch this - and at all other times the rule should just go away.

Just three other points to make regarding these historic EPA regulations.

First, they require regulation of not just mercury, but also a plethora of other hazardous air pollutants that have been so designated because of their carcinogenic or bioaccumulative impacts. These are pollutants such as cadmium, arsenic, hydrogen flourides hydrogen chlorides, etc. the regulation of which is long overdue.

Second, these rules will be a benefit not only to public health, but also to the economy, as they will require the installation of controls of coal fired power plants throughout the country. Such pollution controls cost tens to hundreds of millions of dollars, and require hundreds of skilled laborers to install. That means the creation of good paying, mostly union jobs over the next 3-5 years.

Finally, these rules will finally help trigger the retirement of some aging coal units that were built in the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s, yet are still operating without pollution controls. And that, in turn, will open up space for cleaner forms of energy - wind, solar, energy efficiency, combined heat and power, etc. - to gain a larger foothold in the energy system.

Overall, this is a real win for public health, the economy, and the environment. Let's make sure the GOP does not take it away from us.

The lifeboat analogy presumes that opportunity is a zero-sum game. Opportunity is all around us - but you need the skills and the mentality to get it.

In an opportunity society there are far more lifeboats than in an entitlement society where there are too few. Too few that quickly become overloaded. Everyone drowns.

Seriously though, there are many opportunities flowing by each of us every day like fish in a raging river. All one needs to do is reach in and pull one out. Then the work begins. Unfortunately too many liberals think opportunity means that you get a present at your front door and voila!, you're rich! Don't chastise the wealthy who have worked hard, educated themselves and become wealthy while helping others along the way. Most of these people started out in poverty or the middle class themselves. Their success is only possible in an opportunity society.

An entitlement society says that everybody on the ship is entitled to a place in a lifeboat. So the ship must have enough lifeboats that everyone will have a place. In an opportunity society, everyone has an opportunity to get a place in a lifeboat, but there need not be enough lifeboats so that everyone will succeed. In the opportunity society everyone will try harder; if you knew or suspected there would not be places in the lifeboats for everybody, you would behave differently and might adopt strategies of which you were not at all proud.

When competitive pressures push people to cheat, game the system, look for special angles, or rely on connections to succeed, this is normal and inevitable to an extent. But if it gets out of hand, we have too much competition. Romney (at least today's Romney) does not seem to understand that too much competition is possible, and so he does not see that in many areas too much competition is with us right now.

My humble proposal is interdependency. It applies to human-human relationship; it applies to human-sentient being relationship; it even applies to human-environment relationship. Moral decisions are, first, decisions.

First you have to write the axioms. I'd suggest writing the UN Human Rights into software, and watching it crash.

Try this axiom:

What's best for the majority.

The machines do, as programmed to, what we want them to do: warm up our coffee for 2:33 minutes or drop bombs at a target 1,123.89 miles (it can convert that to Km) away. But we'd need to tell (program) them how to make sure that the coffee doesn't taste burnt or how innocent (or not) the target was of the bombs (or how many people at the target were and were not innocent, according to what we think 'innocent' is).

What we think 'moral' is highly subjective, but since we are also the ones designing, programming these machines, we can only insert our own 'morality' standards into a machine -- if ever we get to that stage.

If we have a self-driven car, sure we can program it to go from Point A to B, via a certain route: if that route is too congested, maybe it can find (through GPS) on its own a route that is less congested, but what if it hits a deer or a person? Does it stop and call the cops and insurance agency and report that? Maybe it can also be programmed to do that, with pictures of the accident, etc. Maybe it can be made to do all that. Still, some one will have to program 'morality' into it, or distinguish between a human and an animal (not that it'd matter, if they are dead).

I may have to develop that software after Christmas, but don't hold your breath.

I am glad you are taking up this issue, but I think you need to talk to the FCC as well as the FAA. While interference with the electrical systems on a plane has always seemed dubious to me, you also need to consider the problems that cell phones, iPads and Kindles can create for the cellular systems on the ground.

While unintentional radiation isn't likely to be an issue for the planes (as your testing has shown), many of these devices are intentional radiators as well. That means they have a cellular radio that communicates with base stations on the ground. Aside from these radios creating a LOT greater interference threat for the electrical systems on the plane, the cellular networks on the ground could also be impacted. Cell phones, iPads and Kindles in airplanes, could potentially interfere with the cell phone networks on the ground with which they are trying to communicate, and it is for this reason that I thought the FCC had raised concerns.
